title: 108_hr3973
content: The "Spending Control Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It extends discretionary spending limits. The Spending Control Act of 2004 extends discretionary spending limits for the general purpose category in new budget authority and outlays. The Spending Control Act of 2004 extends discretionary spending limits for the general purpose category in new budget authority and outlays for fiscal years 2007, 2008, and 2009. The Spending Control Act of 2004 extends discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 2007, 2008, and 2009. In fiscal years 2005 through 2009, advance appropriations exceeding a certain amount will be counted against the spending limits for the year they are enacted. SEC. 3. Extension of pay-as-you-go requirement. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to ensure that any legislation causing a net increase in direct spending before October 1, 2009, will trigger an offsetting sequestration. Timing and calculation methods are also revised. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to eliminate direct spending increases by adjusting calculations and headings. Amendments include removing references to receipts and adjusting wording in various sections of the Act. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to address direct spending increases by adjusting calculations and headings. Amendments involve changing wording in different sections of the Act to reflect an increase or decrease in direct spending. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "advance appropriation" and "emergency requirement" under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Advance appropriation refers to funds becoming available one fiscal year or more beyond the enactment of the appropriation Act. An emergency requirement involves new budget authority and outlays for situations posing a threat to life, property, or national security, requiring immediate action and being unforeseen. The curr_chunk introduces definitions for "unforeseen" emergencies and specifies that they must be temporary in nature. It also clarifies that anticipated emergencies are not considered unforeseen. Additionally, it amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to include contingency operations related to the global war on terrorism. The President designates contingency operations related to the global war on terrorism as a part of the adjustment in appropriations. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include accounts designated in the joint explanatory statement of managers accompanying the conference report on the Spending Control Act of 2004. Section 257(c) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to restrict new budgetary resources designated under certain sections from being assumed beyond the fiscal year they were enacted for. Additionally, an exception is made for outlay components of expiring receipts legislation. SEC. 6 amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to extend certain provisions in tax relief acts. SEC. 7 updates reporting requirements, and SEC. 8 addresses expiration. SEC. 8 amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 by changing expiration dates to 2009 and 2013. SEC. 9 makes technical corrections to the Act. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 include changes to sequestration rules, expenses, committees, and fiscal years. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 involve modifications to various sections, such as inserting words, striking phrases, and adjusting clauses. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 include changes like striking semicolons, replacing words, and correcting spelling errors in specific sections.
